awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding deltas through the lens of their channel networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Sediment deposition at the coastline creates channels that spread out into a network and form a river delta. Deltas are home to large populations, valuable ports, and natural resources, but they are threatened by sea level rise, upstream dam development, and resource exploration. Sensitivity to these threats depends on the delta channels that move water and sediment, yet it is not clear what controls the arrangement of these channels. This research will use network analysis of numerically simulated and field deltas to test how ocean waves, tides, and floods influence the configuration of delta channels and their response to environmental change. The team will engage graduate students through summer workshops and train them in cross-disciplinary methods to address problems in science, industry, and policy-related fields. 

Delta channel networks exhibit complex patterns that are key for understanding delta self-maintenance and resilience to external perturbations. The proposed research aims to study deltas through the lens of their delta channel networks via a three-pronged approach based on graph-theory, numerical modeling, and the analysis of more than 60 field deltas of diverse hydroclimatic environments and levels of anthropogenic influence. The ultimate goal is to advance our understanding of delta morphodynamics and response to change by: (1) relating network properties to the underlying physical processes, (2) proposing a delta classification framework, and (3) exploring delta self-organization in terms of optimality principles and interpreting possible deviations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
River deltas are eco-geomorphologically complex landscapes which are formed and reshaped by the interplay of river, wave, and tidal sediment fluxes. These landscapes serve as the critical interface between the land surface and the ocean by distributing terrestrial fluxes via delta channel networks (DCNs). Although the study of the topology and dynamics of tributary channel networks has been extensively studied over the years, much less work has been done on quantifying the complex topology of river networks in distributary systems. Our project advanced this frontier by developing a graph theoretic treatment of DCN structure and flux distribution, proposed quantitative metrics to compare and contrast these structures, as well as methodologies for studying the resilience of these systems to upstream perturbations and showed that DCNs self-organize to increase the diversity of sediment transport pathways to the shoreline.

As part of this project, we compiled a global database of 52 DCNs and quantified their topology and flux distribution.  Since the level of detail in the extracted DCNs depends on both the spatial resolution of the available imagery and the size of the delta systems themselves, which can vary by orders of magnitude, we proposed the concept of “intrinsic resolution” as a more relevant scale at which DCN comparison and classification should be made.  The intrinsic resolution is defined as the resolution which sufficiently captures the delta flux dynamics, and it was found to emerge naturally as a transition point by progressively removing channels that carry the least flux. This resolution was used for delta classification and comparison.

By analysis of satellite imagery over the past decades it was found that a number of deltas in our global DCN database were found to have prograding channel networks while many others were static. This motivated the questions (1) what controls DCN progradation rate? and (2) why do channels cease to prograde? We hypothesized that a relatively simple hydraulic variable, the average flow velocity at the channel tip, controls both the progradation rate and when deltas cease to grow. Specifically, a threshold flow velocity must be met for channels to grow, below which delta channel tips remain static. We tested this hypothesis and found that it is able to separate static systems from prograding ones, and moreover it provides a framework to predict DCN response to changes in streamflow. Specifically, application of this framework to predict how arctic DCNs may respond to projected climate-induced increased streamflow revealed that this increased streamflow will be insufficient to reactivate these networks. Instead, increased wave activity associated with decreased sea ice extent is expected to lead to the retreat of arctic DCNs.

In addition to DCN structure, delta shoreline structure has long been hypothesized to encode information on the relative influence of fluvial, wave, and tidal processes on delta formation and evolution. However, quantification of shoreline structure has failed to bear out significant differences between visually distinct deltas, limiting our understanding of the connection between process and form and of how deltas might respond to changing forcings. We introduced a novel framework for the multiscale characterization of shorelines by defining three process-targeted morphological metrics and showed that this characterization yields self-emerging classes of morphologically similar deltas, i.e. delta morphotypes. By projecting these emergent delta morphotype classes into a quantitative sediment budget framework based on the relative river, wave and tide sediment fluxes acting on each delta (Galloway diagram) we discovered important similarities between process-based characterization of deltas and their morphological characterization.  

As part of this project, two graduate students and two post-doctoral associates were mentored, developing expertise in this area of research and producing a high level of published peer review work. The project also led to several special sessions organized at the AGU meetings, including an AGU Union session, a workshop that brought together an interdisciplinary group of scientists in hydrology, geomorphology, and computer sciences to advance ideas on data analytics for climate and earth processes, and the SoCal Geomorphology Symposium which brought together more than 40 early career researchers to exchange ideas and build collaborations.
